children.name: Lesson 01: Introduction, History, and Internet Architecture

fields: What are advantages of a network layered architecture?

• Scalability
  • Modularity
  • Flexibility (add or delete components)
What are disadvantages of a network layered architecture?

• Cross-layer dependencies that violate the goal of layer separation
  • Duplicate functionality, i.e. error correction/recovery 
  • Increased overhead in computation and in message headers caused by the abstraction barriers between layers
What are the differences between the OSI model and the five-layered Internet model?
OSI model has 7 layers and five-layered is five layers where the session and presentation layers are combined into the application layer
What are the similarities between the OSI model and the five-layered Internet model?

They both represent layered network architecture with a physical, data link, network, transport, and application layer.and have the same advantages and disadvantages when it comes to utilize a layered architecture.
  • Advantages
    • Scalability
    • Modularity
    • Flexibility (add or delete components)
  • Disadvantages
    • Cross-layer dependencies that violate the goal of layer separation
    • Duplicate functionality, i.e. error recovery 
    • Increased overhead in computation and in message headers caused by the abstraction barriers between layers
{{c1::Sockets}} are the interface between the application and transport layers
What are the 7 layers in the OSI Model?
How many layers are in the OSI Model
What layer of the OSI model maintains connections and is responsible for controlling ports and sessions
What layer of the OSI model defines the format of data on the network
What layer of the OSI model transmits raw bit stream over the physical medium
Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for moving datagrams from on internet host to another?
Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for end to end communication between hosts?
Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for moving frames from one node (host or router) to the next node.
We refer to packets of information as frames in which layer of the OSI model?
Which layer facilitates the interaction with actual hardware via signals.
In Networking, {{c1::encapsulation}} is the process of taking data from one protocol and translating it into data that is used by another protocol as the data continues across a network.
End-hosts implement all five layers, intermediate devices {{c1::don’t::do/dont}}.
According to the e2e principle the network core should be {{c1::simple}} and {{c1::minimal}}, while the end systems should carry the {{c1::intelligence}}.

Moving functions and services closer to the applications that use them, increases the flexibility and the autonomy of the application designer to offer these services to the needs of the specific application. Thus, the higher-level protocol layers, are more specific to an application. Whereas the lower-level protocol layers are free to organize the lower-level network resources to achieve application design goals more efficiently and independently of the specific application.
What are two examples of things that violation of e2e principle?
T/FFirewalls violate the e2e principle since they are intermediate devices operated between two end hosts and can drop the end hosts' communication.
Why do NAT boxes violate the e2e principle?

The hosts behind NAT boxes are not globally addressable or routable. As a result, it is not possible for other hosts on the public Internet to initiate connections to these devices. So, if we have a host behind a NAT and a host on the public Internet, they cannot communicate by default without the intervention of a NAT box.
{{c1::EvoArch}} is a discrete-time model that is executed over rounds which can help illustrate layered {{c2::architectures}} and their evolution in a {{c2::quantitative}} manner.
Repeaters and hubs operate on what layer of the OSI Model?
Bridges operate on what layer of the OSI Model?
Data Link Layer (L2) along with Layer2-Switches
Routers operate on what layer of the OSI Model?
A bridge is a device with multiple inputs/outputs. A bridge transfers frames from an input to one or more outputs.

It learns by populating/maintaing a forwarding table. When the bridge receives any frame this is a “learning opportunity” to know which hosts are reachable through which ports. This is because the bridge can view the port over which a frame arrives and the source host. Going back to our example topology, eventually the bridge builds the following forwarding table.
What is the combination of the segment and the network header called?

T/F
The e2e principle suggests that specific application-level functions usually can, and preferably should be built into the lower levels of the system at the core of the network.

FALSE
The e2e principle suggests that specific application-level functions usually cannot, and preferably should not be built into the lower levels of the system at the core of the network. The e2e principle is summarized as: the network core should be simple and minimal, while the end systems should carry the intelligence.

The data is sent down each layer of the OSI Model building a Protocol Data Unit (PDU) or Package by wrapping the data with header and optionally trailer information, both of which contain control information to the PDU from the layer above.
A recieving node or itermidary read/strip layers of the Package to get to address information so that it can be redirected or assembled with other packages at the destination.

Connecting two computers over a dial-up telephone line

Translate domain names into IP addresses

At the edges of a network

They operate on different layers of the IP stack

What is the purpose of the EvoArch Model?

• Illustrate layered architectures and their evolution in a quantitative manner.
  • Propose a possible explanation for how the Hourglass shape of the layered stack of the Internet arose.
  • Suggest how future architectures can be "more evolveable" without the ossification of middle layers
In the OSI Model what layer is responsible for the mechanism that manages the different transport streams that belong to the same session between end-user application processes.

Some data link layer protocols, such 802.11 (WiFi), implement some basic error correction as the physical medium used is easily prone to interference and noise (such as a nearby running microwave). Is this a violation of the end-to-end principle?
Using bridges to connect LANs fails if the network topology results in a {{c1::loop}}.
When a bridge receives a frame, it learns which {{c1::host}} can be reached on which ​ {{c2::port}} and adds this to a ​ {{c3::forwarding table}}.

One difference between the 7-layer OSI Model and the 5-layer Model of the Internet is that the 5-layer model combines the​ {{c1::session}}, ​ {{c2::presenation}}, and {{c3::application}} layers into one {{c4::application}} layer.
Node \(u\) uses the services of this set of nodes
The set of all nodes that depend upon node \(u\)
The probability that a new node in layer \(l+1\) will select each node in layer \(l\) as a substrate.
A value computed recursively based on the products of \(u\)
The same-level nodes that share at least a fraction c of node \(u\)’s products
What are some DISADVANTAGES the layered protocol stack?

• One layer may duplicate lower layer functionalities.
  • Some layers functionality depends on the information from other layers, which can violate the goal of layer separation.
  • Separating the layers creates additional overhead

During a run of the Spanning Tree Algorithm, a node stops sending configuration messages over a port when the node receives a configuration message that indicates that it is not the root. This occurs when the node receives a configuration message from a neighbor that is either ​{{c1::closer to}} the root or has the ​ {{c2::same}} distance from the root, but it has a(n)​ {{c3::smaller}} ID.
Which of the following are ramifications of the “hourglass shape of the internet”?

• Many technologies that were not originally designed for the internet have been modified so that they have versions that can communicate over the internet (such as Radio over IP).
  • It has been a difficult and slow process to transition to IPv6, despite the shortage of public IPv4 addresses.
In the EvoArch Model, every node has at least one substrate, except the nodes at the​ {{c1::bottom}} layer. Conversely, every node has at least one product, except nodes at the {{c2::top}} layer.
The process by which each layer appends its own header to the message from the layer above it is called.
The process by which each layer strips its own header off of the message from the layer below it is called.

During a round of the Spanning Tree Algorithm, a node selects one configuration as better if the root of the configuration has a ​{{c1::smaller}} ID. If the roots have {{c2::equal}} IDs, then the configuration with a {{c3::smaller}} distance from the root is selected. However, if both root IDs are the same and the distances from the root are the same, then the node breaks the tie by selecting the configuration of the sending node that has with the {{c3::smallest}} ID.
What is the order of precidence in the spanning tree algorithm.

1. Smaller Root ID
  2. Smaller Distance from the Root
  3. Smaller Sending Node ID
In the OSI model, the {{c1::Presentation}} layer plays the intermediate role of formatting the information that it receives from the layer below and delivering it to the {{c2::application}} layer.
The Spanning Tree Algorithm helps to prevent  what?
A transport layer level segment combined with a network layer header is called a ...
What protocol offers a connection-oriented service to the applications that are running on the layer above to ensure reliable application-level message delivery.
What protocol provides a connectionless best-effort service to the applications that are running in the layer above, without reliability.
End hosts implement layers {{c1::1-5}}. Routers implement layers {{c2::1-3}} , and layer-2 switches implement layers {{c3::1-2}}.
What is the Domain Name System (DNS) designed to do primarily?
Translate domain names into IP addresses
What is the architectural design of the Internet protocol stack based on?
In the OSI Model, the {{c1::session}} layer is responsible for the mechanism that manages the different transport streams that belong to the same session between end-user application processes.
In this method of congestion control, the hosts infer congestion from the network behavior and adapt the transmission rate.
In TCP Fairness, for the \(k\) connections passing through one common link with capacity \(R\) bps, each connection gets an average throughput of?
Which application-layer protocol(s) typically depend(s) on UDP as an underlying transport-layer protocol? Select all that apply.

How does TCP CUBIC calculate \(K\) (the time period that it takes to increase the congestion window (\(W\)) to \(Wmax\) when there is no further loss event)?
\(K=\sqrt[3]{\frac{Wmax \beta }{C}}\)
Uses the time elapsed since the last lost event
What are two signals used by a host to infer congestion in end-to-end congestion control?

• The receiver sends an ACK for the most recently received in-order packet
  • The receiver discards any out-of-order received packets
  • The sender resends all packets from the most recently ACKed in-order packet
What are the goals of congestion control?

TCP uses {{c1::congestion}} window similar to the receive window used for flow control. It represents the maximum number of unacknowledged data that a sending host can have in transit (sent but not yet acknowledged).
What are two cautions about fairness cases when TCP is not fair? Select all that apply.

• Connections with smaller RTT values would increase their congestion window faster than those with longer RTT values
  • A new application with multiple parallel TCP connections would get an unfair allocation of the transmission rate than multiple applications using one TCP connection sharing a link.

• The receiver acknowledges a correctly received packet even if it is not in order.
  • Any out-of-order packets the receiver acknowledges remain in the buffer until missing packets are received.
  • The sender retransmits packets it suspects were received in error.
The job of delivering the data included in the transport-layer segment to the appropriate socket, as defined in the segment fields, is called?
What method of congestion control does TCP implement today?
Using the Go-back-N method, a single packet error can cause a lot of unnecessary retransmissions. What does TCP implement to solve for this problem?

The sending host will need to gather data from different sockets and encapsulate each data chunk with header information to create segments, and then forward the segments to the network layer.
We refer to this job as​?
Which application-layer protocol(s) typically depend(s) on TCP as an underlying transport-layer protocol?

When the sender receives ​ {{c1::3}} duplicate ACKs for a packet, it considers the packet to be lost and will retransmit it instead of waiting for the timeout. This is known as {{c2::fast retransmit}}.
In Flow Control, the receiver advertises what value in every segment/ACK it sends back to the sender?
The method of using acknowledgments from the receiving host and timeouts (when no acknowledgement is received in a set amount of time) to ensure reliable transmission over TCP is known as:
TCP CUBIC is {{c1::RRT-fair}} and TCP Reno is {{c2::not}} since it is based on {{c3::ACK RTT}}
In this method of congestion control, the network layer provides explicit feedback to the sender about congestion in the network.
What is the purpose of Flow Control?

• Control the Transmission Rate to protect the receiver buffer.
  • Avoid congestion in the network.
  • Help match the sender’s rate against the receiver’s rate of reading the data.
The simplest implementation of the Automatic Repeat Request (ARQ) method is known as ....
What are some methods of ensuring reliable transmissions?
Due to congestion control, a TCP sender cannot send ​ {{c1::faster}} than the {{c2::slowest}} component, which is either the network or the receiving host.
TCP utilizes the {{c1::Additive Increase Multiplicative Decrease}} policy for fairness.

One method for Reliable Transmission is for the receiver to send an ACK for the most recently received in-order packet. The sender would then send all packets from the most recently received in-order packet, even if some of them had been sent before. The receiver can simply discard any out-of-order received packets. This is called {{c1::Go-back-N}}.

In Flow Control, the sender maintains a variable ​ {{c1::\(rwnd\)}} that represents how much data the receiver can handle at the moment. The value is determined by:
\({{c2::rwnd}}={{c2::RcvBuffer}}-[{{c3::LastByteRcvd}}-{{c4::LastByteRead}}]\)
In the slow start phase of TCP Reno, the congestion window is increased {{c1::exponentially}} instead of {{c2::linearly}} like Additive Increase Multiplicative Decrease (AIMD).

In Flow Control, a receiving host maintains a receive buffer of size \({{c1::RcvBuffer}}\). To avoid overflowing this buffer, the receiving host also maintains two variables \({{c2::LastByteRead}}\) and \({{c3::LastByteReceived}}\), maintaining that:
\({{c4::LastByteRcvd}}-{{c5::LastByteRead}}<={{c6::RcvBuffer}}\)
As we have seen, UDP and TCP use port numbers to identify the sending application and destination application. Why don’t UDP and TCP just use process IDs rather than define port numbers?

A single process can set up multiple channels of communications and thus multiple process IDs as the destination identifier wouldn’t be able to properly demultiplex.Finally, having one or more processes listen on well-known ports (like 80 for http) is an important convention.

UDP and TCP use 1’s complement for their checksums. But why is it that UDP takes the 1’s complement of the sum – why not just use the sum? Exploring this further, using 1’s complement, how does the receiver compute and detect errors? Using 1’s complement, is it possible that a 1-bit error will go undetected? What about a 2-bit error?

To detect errors, the receiver adds the four words (the three original words and the checksum).If the sum contains a zero, the receiver knows there has been an error.
  • All one-bit errors will be detected.
  • two-bit errors can be undetected.
If the last digit of the first word is converted to a 0 and the last digit of the second word is converted to a 1.

T/F
The transport layer protocols offer a logical connection between processes only if the hosts reside in the same network.

T/F
A sender host receives a message from the application layer it encapsulates it with the transport layer header before passing it down to the network layer.

T/F
A host cannot maintain a TCP socket and a UDP socket simultaneously.

T/F
The identifier of a UDP socket is a tuple of destination IP address and port.

T/F
The identifier of a TCP socket is a tuple of source IP address and port.

T/F
UDP is considered more lightweight than TCP.

T/F
One of the functionalities that UDP offers is to increase or decrease the pace with which the sender sends data to the receiver.

T/F
Assume Hosts A, B, and C. Host A has a UDP socket with port 123. Hosts B and C each send their own UDP segment to Host A. Hosts B and C cannot use the same destination port 123 for sending their UDP segment.

T/F
TCP offers in-order delivery of the packets, flow control, and congestion control.

T/F
TCP detects packet loss using timeouts and triple duplicate acknowledgements.

T/F
Flow control is a rate control mechanism to protect the receiver’s buffer from overflowing.

T/F
Congestion control is a rate control mechanism to protect the network from congestion.

T/F
In TCP, the number of unacknowledged segments that a sender can have is the minimum of the congestion window and the receive window.

T/F
Consider the TCP Reno, congestion window is cut in half in both of the following events occour:
  1. timeout occurs
  2. triple duplicate acknowledgement

T/F
Consider a TCP connection and a diagram showing the congestion as it progresses. From the diagram, when we observe the congestion window drop to its initial value, we infer that a packet loss occurred.

T/F
Consider a TCP connection, and a diagram that shows how the congestion window progresses over time. From the diagram we can identify the time periods of slow start when the congestion window increases by 1 every RTT.

T/F
TCP Cubic was designed for better network utilization.

T/F
TCP Cubic congestion window growth function is designed to not overflow the receiver’s buffer.

T/F
 TCP Cubic uses a cubic function to increase the congestion window.

T/F
TCP Cubic increases the congestion window in every RTT.

Characteristics of TCP Reno
  • When a triple duplicate ACK occurs, the congestion window is {{c1::cut in half}}
  • When a timeout event occurs, the congestion window is {{c2::reset}} to the initial window size

how routers work together using routing protocols to determine good paths across different administrative domains

What is the problem with using current load as a weight with link-state algorithms?
The weighs are not static and change dramatically as traffic moves over the network. This is a non-trivial problem which can cause pathological behavior.
T/FUpon termination of Dijkstra’s algorithm, all nodes in a network are aware of the entire network topology.

choosing the closest egress point based on intradomain path cost (Interior Gateway Protocol/IGP cost).

  • Updates resulting from an {{c1::increase}} in link cost travel {{c2::slowly}}
  • Updates resulting from an {{c1::decrease}} in link cost travel {{c2::quickly}}
What are the key characteristics of the Distance Vector Routing Algorithm?

• Based on the Bellman Ford Algorithm
  • The stopping condition is when all nodes stop sending updates to their neighbors
  • t's an iterative, asynchronous and distributed algorithm
What happens during the iterative part of the Linkstate Routing Algorithm?

1. look at the set of nodes that are NOT included in \(N’\), and we identify the node (say \(w\)) with the least cost path from the previous iteration
  2. We add the node w (that has the least cost path from the previous iteration) into \(N’\)
  3. For every neighbor \(v\) of \(w\), we update \(D(v)\) (cost of the current least cost path from \(w\) to \(v\))
In what cases does Poison Reverse solve the Count to Infinity Problem?

Intradomain routing must involves how many administrative domains?
What are the main characteristics of Hot Potato routing?

• it effectively reduces the network’s resource consumption by getting the traffic out as soon as possible
  • it chooses the closest egress point based on intradomain path cost (Interior Gateway Protocol/IGP cost)
  • it's an intradomain routing technique
T/FHot Potato routing is an intradomain routing technique.
T/FHow does Hot Potato routing choose its egress point?
based on intradomain path cost (Interior Gateway Protocol/IGP cost)

getting the traffic out as soon as possible
What chracteristics do nodes have in the Distance Vector Routing Algorithm?

• A node's distance vector is the vector of cost estimates from itself to all other nodes
  • Each node maintains its view of the network in a table
  • Nodes only update its direct neighbors when its least-cost path changes
In what algorithms does a node maintain its view of the network in a table?
What happens during the Initialization stage of the Linkstate Routing Algorithm?

1. We initialize all the currently known least-cost paths from a source node \(u\) to its directly attached neighbors \(v\)
  2. For nodes that are not directly attached to the source node \(u\) , initialize the cost to ∞
  3. initialize the set \(N'\) to include only the source node \(u\)
What are some characteristics of the Linkstate Routing Algorithm?

• Uses Dijkstra’s algorithm
  • The link costs and the network topology are known to ALL nodes
  • The goal of the algorithm is to compute the least cost paths from a source node to all other nodes
In RIP (Routing Information Protocol) how are routing updates exchanged between neighbors?
By using RIP advertisements with messages

In this lecture, we discuss intradomain routing, where all the nodes and subnets are owned and managed by the same organization. (In contrast, interdomain routing is about routing between different organizations – such as between two ISPs.) Before we begin talking about intradomain routing algorithms, what could the weights on the graph edges represent in these diagrams, when we are seeking the least-cost path between two nodes?

• look at the set of nodes that are NOT included in \(N’N’N’\), and we identify the node (say \(www\)) with the least cost path from the previous iteration
  • We add the node\(WWW\) (that has the least cost path from the previous iteration) into \(N’N’N’\)
  • For every neighbor of \(vvv\) of \(w\), we update\(D(v)D(v)D(v)\) (cost of the current least cost path from  \(www\) to \(vvv\))

how routers work together using routing protocols to determine good paths across different administrative domains

The Bellman Ford equation is used by the ​ {{c1::distance vector}} algorithm.

In the previous example, node \(u\) was the source node, and distances were calculated from \(u\) to each other node. Consider the same example, but let \(x\) be the source node. Notice that node \(x\) has more direct neighbors than u does. Suppose \(x\) is executing the linkstate algorithm as discussed, and has just finished the initialization step.What is true in comparing the number of iterations between node \(x\) and node \(u\)?
Node \(x\) will execute the same number of iterations that node \(u\) did, as the number of immediate neighbors has no impact on the number of iterations the algorithm requires.

T/F
Intradomain routing refers to routing that takes place among routers that belong to the same administrative domain. In contrast when routers belong to different administrative domains, we refer to routing as interdomain routing.

T/F
Consider the link-state routing protocol. The link costs are known to all nodes.

T/F
Consider the link-state routing protocol and a node u as our source node. The goal of the algorithm is to compute the least-cost paths from the source node u to every other node in the network.

T/F
The distance vector (DV) routing algorithm continues iterating as long as neighbors send new updates to each other.

T/F

The distance vector (DV) routing algorithm is an example of a {{c1::decentralized}} algorithm.

The distance vector (DV) routing algorithm requires synchronization between routers.

T/F
In the distance vector (DV) routing algorithm, each node maintains and updates its own view of the network.
Consider the distance (DV) routing algorithm. Which is used by each node to update the node’s distance vector?

T/F
The count-to-infinity problem states that good news (e.g., a decrease in a link cost) propagates slowly among nodes in the network.

T/F

T/F
The Routing Information Protocol (RIP) is based on the Distance Vector protocol.

T/F
Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) is based on the link state routing algorithm.

T/F
The number of egress points that a network has is upper bounded, e.g., two or three egress points per network.

T/F
Consider a network with multiple egress points. Further consider that these egress points offer different paths to the same external destinations. Then these paths must have different costs.

T/F
According to the hot potato routing technique, it is in a network’s best interest to route the traffic so that it exits the network at the router geographically closest to the one from which it entered the network.

T/F
Assume a source and a destination host. As packets travel over a path from the source host to the destination host the packets are handled by multiple routers over that path. If these routers belong to different administrative domains, they need to run the same intradomain routing algorithm, since they are on the same path for that pair of hosts.
T/FThe count-to-infinity problem states that bad news (e.g., a increase in a link cost) propagates fast among nodes in the network.

{{c1::Route filters}} are rules that determine which routes an AS's router should advertise to the routers of neighboring ASes.

What are the key points of using Multibit Tries Fixed-Length Stride?

• Every element in a trie represents two pieces of information: a pointer and a prefix value.
  • The prefix search moves ahead with the preset length in n-bits
  • When the path is traced by a pointer, we remember the last matched prefix (if any).
  • Our search ends when an empty pointer is met. At that time, we return the last matched prefix as our final prefix match.

characteristics of the Knockout Scheme:
  • It is {{c1::complex}} to implement and makes assumptions about {{c2::traffic distributions}}

Differences between Token Bucket policing and shaping:
  • They both {{c1::limit}} the output rate of a link by identifying {{c2::traffic descriptor violations}}, but they respond to these violations in {{c3::different}} ways
  • With {{c4::Policing}}, when the traffic rate reaches the maximum configured rate, excess traffic is {{c5::dropped}}, or the packet's {{c6::setting or "marking"}} is changed. The output rate appears as a {{c7::saw-toothed}} wave.
  • A {{c8::shaper}} typically retains excess packets in a {{c9::queue or a buffer}}, and this excess is {{c10::scheduled for later transmission}}. The result is that excess traffic is {{c11::delayed}} instead of dropped.

Characteristics of token bucket shaping:
  • Addresses the scenario in which we want to set {{c1::bandwidth guarantees}} for flows in the same queue without {{c2::separating}} them
  • Can limit the {{c3::burstiness of a flow}} by limiting the {{c4::average rate}} and by limiting the {{c5::maximum burst size}}
  • Uses {{c6::one}} queue(s) per flow
  • Excess traffic is {{c7::delayed}}
  • The output rate appears as a {{c8::smoothed}} wave.

Reasons to make scheduling decisions more complex than FIFO with tail drop:
  • Router support for {{c1::congestion}}
  • {{c2::Fair}} sharing of links among {{c3::competing flows}}
  • Providing {{c4::Quality of Service (QoS)}} guarantees to {{c5::flows}}

Characteristics of bit-by-bit Round Robin:
  • was developed to {{c1::ensure fairness}} in {{c2::bandwidth}} allocation
  • The rate of {{c3::increase}} in round number is {{c4::inversely}} proportional to the number of {{c5::active flows}}
  • provides {{c6::bandwidth}} and {{c7::delay}} guarantees

Ways to avoid the head-of-line blocking problem:
  • Using {{c1::output queuing}} ({{c2::Knockout scheme}})
  • Using {{c3::parallel iterative}} matching

Characteristics of Deficit Round Robin (DRR):
  • only provides {{c1::bandwidth}} guarantees -- not {{c2::delay}} guarantees
  • it's a {{c3::constant}} time algorithm
  • for each {{c4::flow}} {{c5::i}}, the algorithm keeps a {{c6::quantum size}} {{c7::Qi}} and a {{c8::deficit counter}} {{c9::Di}}
  • {{c10::Deficits}} are carried over to the {{c11::next round}}

Characteristics of the Grid of Tries approach to packet classification:
  • Uses {{c1::precomputed}} switch pointers to avoid {{c2::backtracking}}
  • Reduces {{c3::time complexity}} associated with {{c4::backtracking}}
  • Keeps track of our current {{c5::best source}} match and skips {{c6::source tries}} that are {{c7::shorter}} than that match

Characteristics of Leaky Bucket Algorithm:
  • Can be used in both traffic {{c1::policing}} and traffic {{c1::shaping}}.
  • If the bucket is {{c1::full}}, the new packet that arrives to the bucket is {{c1::dropped}}.
  • The leak rate is a {{c1::constant}} rate at which the packets are {{c1::allowed to enter}} the network

  3. {{c1::Accept}} Phase: inputs that receive multiple grants {{c2::randomly pick}} an output to send to.

  • With Policing, when the traffic rate reaches the maximum configured rate, excess traffic is {{c1::dropped}}, or the packet's s{{c2::etting or "marking"}} is changed.

SDNs were created due to challenges of managing networks for two main reasons:
  • {{c1::Diversity of equipment}} on the network
  • {{c2::Proprietary technologies}} for the equipment

The history of SDN can be divided into three phases:
  1. {{c1::Active}} networks
  2. {{c2::Control and data plane}} separation
  3. {{c3::OpenFlow API}} and {{c4::network operating systems}}
The {{c1::active networks}} phase took place from the mid-{{c2::1990s}} to the early {{c3::2000s}}.

In the history of SDN researchers were keen on testing new ideas to improve network services. However, this required standardization of new protocols by the {{c1::IETF (Internet Engineering Task Force)::group}}, which was a slow and frustrating process.

In the early 1990s, the networking approach was primarily via {{c1::IP}}or {{c1::ATM (Asynchronous Transfer Mode)}}. Active networking became one of the first {{c2::‘clean slate’}} approaches to network architecture.

During the active networks phase of SDN history There the two types of programming models in active networking were:
  1. {{c1::Capsule}} model – carried {{c2::in-band}} in data packets
  2. {{c1::Programmable router/switch}} model – established by {{c2::out-of-band}} mechanisms.
During the {{c3::Active Networks}} phase of SDN history {{c1::Programmable routers}} made {{c2::decision making}} a job for the {{c3::network operator}}.

The pushes that encouraged active networking were:
  • Reduction in {{c1::computation cost}}
  • Advancement in {{c1::programming languages}}
  • Advances in rapid code {{c1::compilation}} and {{c1::formal}} methods.
  • Funding from agencies such as {{c1::DARPA (U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency::Government Organization)}} for a collection promoted interoperability amoung projects.

The use pulls for active networking were:
  • {{c1::Network service provider}} frustration concerning the long timeline to {{c1::develop and deploy}} new network services.
  • Third party interests to add value by implementing {{c1::control at a more individualistic nature}}.
  • Researchers interest in having a network that would {{c1::support large-scale experimentation}}.
  • Unified control over {{c1::middleboxes}}.

In addition to the push and pull use cases, active networks made three major contributions related to SDN:

  • {{c1::Programmable functions}} in the network to lower the barrier to innovation
  • {{c2::Network virtualization}}, and the ability to demultiplex to software programs based on {{c3::packet headers}}.
  • The vision of a unified architecture for {{c4::middlebox orchestration}}
The {{c1::Control and data plane separation}} phase lasted from around {{c2::2001}} to {{c2::2007}}.

The technology pushes that encouraged control and data plane separation were:
  • Higher link speeds in backbone networks led vendors to {{c1::implement packet forwarding directly in the hardware, thus separating it from the control-plane software}}.
  • Internet Service Providers (ISPs) found it hard to meet the increasing demands for {{c2::greater reliability}} and {{c2::new services (such as virtual private networks)}}, and struggled to {{c3::manage the increased size and scope of their networks}}.
  • Servers had substantially more memory and processing resources than those deployed one-two years prior. This meant that a single server could {{c4::store all routing states and compute all routing decisions for a large ISP network}}.
  • {{c5::Open source routing software}} lowered the barrier to creating prototype implementations of centralized routing controllers.

The technology pushes inspired two main innovations:
  • {{c1::Open interface}} between {{c2::control and data}} planes
  • {{c1::Logically centralized}} control of the {{c2::network}}

The Control and dataplane seperation phase was different from active networking phase in several ways:
  • It focused on spurring innovation by and for {{c1::network administrators}} rather than {{c1::end users and researchers}}.
  • It emphasized programmability in the {{c2::control}} domain rather than the {{c2::data}} domain.
  • It worked towards network-wide {{c3::visibility and control}} rather than device-level {{c3::configurations}}.

Some use pulls for the control and data plane seperation were:
  • Selecting between network paths based on the {{c1::current traffic load}}
  • Minimizing disruptions during {{c2::planned routing changes}}
  • Redirecting/dropping {{c3::suspected attack traffic}}
  • Allowing customer networks more control over {{c4::traffic flow}}
  • Offering value-added services for {{c5::virtual private network customers}}

The attempt to separate the control and data planes resulted in a couple of concepts which were used in further SDN design:
  • {{c1::Logically centralized control}} using an {{c1::open interface}} to the data plane.
  • {{c2::Distributed}} state management.
The {{c1::OpenFlow API and network operating systems}} phase took place from around {{c2::2007}} to {{c2::2010}}.

The basic working of an OpenFlow switch is as follows:
  • Each switch contains {{c1::a table of packet-handling}} rules.
  • Each rule has {{c2::a pattern}}, list of {{c3::actions}}, set of {{c3::counters}} and a {{c3::priority}}.
  • When an OpenFlow switch receives a packet, it determines {{c3::the highest priority matching rule}}, performs {{c3::the action associated with it}} and {{c3::increments the counter.

OpenFlow was adopted in the industry, unlike its predecessors. This could be due to:
  • Before OpenFlow, switch chipset vendors had already started to {{c1::allow programmers to control some forwarding behaviors}}.
  • This allowed more companies to build switches without having to {{c2::design and fabricate their own data plane}}.
  • Early OpenFlow versions built on technology that {{c3::the switches already supported}}. This meant that enabling OpenFlow initially was as simple as {{c4::performing a firmware upgrade}}!

Open Flow API and Network Operating System Use pulls:
  • OpenFlow came up to meet the need of {{c1::conducting large scale experimentation on network architectures}}.
  • OpenFlow was useful in {{c2::data-center networks}} – there was a need to manage network traffic at large scales.
  • Companies started investing more in {{c3::programmers to write control programs}}, and less in {{c3::proprietary switches that could not support new features easily}}.

Some key effects that OpenFlow had were:
  • Generalizing {{c1::network devices and functions}}.
  • The vision of a {{c2::network operating system}}.
  • Distributed {{c3::state management techniques}}.

One of the main differences between the {{c1::Active Networks}} phase and the {{c1::separation of the Control and Data plane}} phase is that the former is focused on {{c2::device-level configurations}} and the latter is focused on {{c2::network-wide visibility and control}}.

T/F

One of the downfalls of OpenFlow when it was first created was that it was hard to deploy and scale it easily.

False

Early OpenFlow versions built on technology that the switches already supported. This meant that enabling OpenFlow initially was as simple as performing a firmware upgrade!

The reasons we separate the data plane from the control plane in SDN are:
  1. {{c1::Independent evolution and development}}
    - Traditional routers are responsible for both {{c2::routing and forwarding}}.
    - A change to either of the functions requires {{c2::an upgrade of hardware}}.
    - In this new approach, routers only focus on {{c2::forwarding}}.
  2. {{c1::Control from high-level software program}}
    - In SDN, we use {{c2::software}} to compute the forwarding tables.

This Control Plane and Data Plane separation leads to opportunities in different areas:
  1. {{c1::Data centers}}
  2. {{c1::Routing}}
  3. {{c1::Enterprise networks}}
  4. {{c1::Research networks}}

In control plane and data plane seperation there are two important functions of the network layer are:
  1. {{c1::Forwarding}}
  2. {{c1::Routing}}
In the traditional approach, the routing algorithms (control plane) and forwarding function (data plane) are {{c1::closely}} coupled.
The router runs and participates in the routing algorithms.

The main components of an SDN network are: 
  • {{c1::SDN-controlled}} network elements
    • Sometimes called the {{c2::infrastructure}} layer, is responsible for {{c3::the forwarding of traffic}} in a network based on the {{c3::rules computed by the SDN control plane}}.
  • {{c1::SDN}} controller
    • A logically centralized entity that acts as an interface between {{c4::the network elements}} and the {{c4::network-control applications}}.
  • {{c1::Network-control}} applications
    • Programs that {{c5::manage the underlying network}} by {{c6::collecting information about the network elements}} with the help of {{c6::SDN controller}}.

The four defining features in an SDN architecture are:
  1. {{c1::Flow-based}} forwarding
  2. Separation of {{c1::data plane and control plane}}
  3. {{c1::Network control}} functions
  4. {{c1::A programmable}} network

Which plane do the SDN components belong to?
  • Network-control applications: {{c1::Control}} plane
  • SDN controller: {{c2::Control}} plane
  • SDN-controlled network elements: {{c3::Data}} plane
The SDN controller is a part of the SDN {{c1::control}} plane and acts as an interface between {{c2::the network elements}} and {{c2::the network-control applications}}.

An SDN controller can be broadly split into three layers: 
  • {{c1::Communication}} layer: communicating between {{c2::the controller}} and the {{c2::network elements}}
  • {{c1::Network-wide state-management}} layer: {{c3::stores information of network-state}}
  • {{c1::Interface to the network-control application}} layer: {{c4::communicating between controller and applications}}

• {{c1::Network-wide state-management}} layer: This layer is about {{c2::the network-state}} that is maintained by the controller.
  • The {{c2::network-state}} includes any information about {{c3::the state of the hosts, links, switches and other controlled elements in the network::list 3}}. It also includes {{c4::copies of the flow tables of the switches}}. 
  • {{c2::Network-state information}} is needed by {{c5::the SDN control plane}} to configure {{c6::the flow tables}}.

The interface to the {{c1::network-control application}} layer:
  • Also known as the controller’s “{{c2::northbound::direction}}”
  • The SDN controller interacts with {{c1::network-control applications}}.
  • They can read/write {{c3::network state}} and {{c3::flow tables}} in controller’s {{c4::state-management layer}}.
  • The SDN controller can notify applications of {{c5::changes in the network state}}.
  • A {{c6::REST interface}} is an example of a {{c2::northbound API}}.

The SDN controller, although viewed as a monolithic service by external devices and applications, is implemented by {{c1::distributed servers}} to achieve {{c2::fault tolerance}}, {{c3::high availability}} and {{c3::efficiency}}. Despite the issues of synchronization across servers, many modern controllers such as {{c3::OpenDayLight}} and {{c3::ONOS}} have solved it and prefer distributed controllers to provide highly scalable services.
Software Defined Networking (SDN) arose as part of the process to make computer networks more {{c1::programmable}}.
SDNs divide the network in two planes: {{c1::control}} plane and {{c1::data}} plane, to {{c2::ease management}} and speed up {{c2::innovation}}.
One of the biggest downfalls for active networking was that it was {{c1::too ambitious!}}

An OpenFlow switch has a table of {{c1::packet-handling rules}}, and whenever it receives a packet, it determines the {{c1::highest priority matching}} rule, {{c1::performs the action associated with it}} and {{c1::increments the respective counter}}.

{{c1::Forwarding}} is a local function for routers, and it usually takes place in {{c2::nanoseconds::timescale}} and is implemented in {{c3::the hardware}} itself. In an SDN Forwarding is a function of the {{c4::data}} plane. A router looks at the header of an incoming packet and consults {{c5::the forwarding table}}, to determine the outgoing link to send the packet to.

{{c1::Routing}} involves determining the {{c6::path from the sender to the receiver across the network}}. Routers rely on routing algorithms for this purpose. It is an end-to-end process for networks. It usually takes place in {{c7::seconds::timescale}} and is implemented in {{c8::the software}}. Routing is a function of the {{c9::control}} plane.

In the traditional approach, the {{c1::routing algorithms}} (control plane) and {{c1::forwarding function}} (data plane) are closely coupled. The router runs and participates in the routing algorithms. From there it is able to construct the {{c1::forwarding table}} which consults it for the forwarding function.
SDNs use {{c1::Software}} to control the routers’ behavior (e.g., the path selection process).

With the separation of the {{c1::control}} plane and the {{c1::data}} plane, any change to the forwarding functions on a router is {{c1::independent from}} the routing functions of the {{c1::control}} plane.
In the SDN approach, the controller that computes and distributes the forwarding tables to be used by the routers is {{c1::Physically separate from the routers}}.
Software implementations in SDN controllers are increasingly open and publicly available, which {{c1::Speeds up}} innovation in the field.

{{c1::Flow-based forwarding:}}
The rules for forwarding packets in the SDN-controlled switches can be computed based on {{c2::any number of header field values in various layers such as the transport-layer, network-layer and link-layer}}. OpenFlow allows up to {{c3::11}} header field values to be considered.

{{c1::Separation of data plane and control plane:}}
The SDN-controlled switches execute {{c2::the rules in the flow tables}}. Those rules are computed, installed, and managed by software that runs on {{c3::separate servers::locality}}.

{{c1::Network control functions:}} 
The SDN control plane consists of two components: {{c2::the controller}} and {{c3::the network applications}}. The controller {{c4::maintains up-to-date network state information about the network devices and elements}} and provides it to the {{c5::network-control applications}}. This information, in turn, is used by the {{c6::applications to monitor and control}} the network devices.

{{c1::A programmable network:}}
The network-control applications act as the {{c2::“brain”}} of SDN control plane by {{c3::managing the network}}.
The network-control applications use the information about the {{c1::network devices and elements}}, provided by the controller, to {{c1::monitor and control}} the network devices.

In an SDN, the controller is responsible for the {{c1::routing}} of the traffic, and the SDN-controlled network elements such as the switches are responsible for the {{c1::forwarding}} of the traffic.
Traffic forwarding can be based on any number of {{c1::header field}} values in various layers like the t{{c1::ransport-layer}}, {{c1::network-layer}} and {{c1::link-layer}}.

An SDN controller can be broadly split into three layers: 
  • {{c1::Communication}} layer: communicating between the {{c1::controller and the network}} elements
  • {{c1::Network-wide state-management}} layer: stores information of {{c1::network-state}}
  • Interface to the {{c1::network-control application}} layer:  communicating between {{c1::controller and applications}}
The {{c1::northbound}} interface is used by the {{c1::controller}} and the {{c1::network-control}} applications to interact with each other.
A REST interface is an example of a {{c1::northbound}} API.
SDN controllers that are implemented by {{c1::decentralized}} servers are more likely to achieve fault tolerance, high availability and efficiency.

A few of the main reasons that SDN arose are:
  • A diversity of {{c1::different network equipment}} (eg routers, switches, firewalls, etc.) using different {{c1::protocols}} that made managing the network difficult.
  • A lack of a {{c1::central platform}} to control network equipment.
The main idea behind SDNs is to divide tasks into {{c1::smaller functions}} so the code is more {{c1::modular}} and {{c1::easy to manage.}}
With SDNs the {{c1::control}} plane and {{c1::data}} plane have independent evolution and development.

By separating the {{c1::control}} plane and the {{c1::data}} plane, controlling the router’s behavior became easier using higher order programs. For example, it is easier to update the router’s {{c1::state}} or c{{c1::ontrol the path selection}}.
In the SDN approach, {{c1::ISPs or other third parties}} can take up the responsibility for {{c1::computing}} and {{c1::distributing}} the router’s forwarding tables.
Having the software implementations for SDNs controllers increasingly open and publicly available makes it {{c1::easy}} to control, since any person could modify the software easily.

As IP networks grew in adoption worldwide, there were a few challenges that became more and more pronounced, such as:
  1. Handling the {{c1::ever-growing complexity and dynamic nature}} of networks
  2. Tightly coupled {{c1::architecture}}

Traditionally viewed, computer networks have three planes of functionality, which are all abstract logical concepts:

  • {{c1::Data}} plane: These are functions and processes that forward {{c1::data in the form of packets or frames}}.
  • {{c1::Control}} plane: These refer to functions and processes that determine {{c1::which path to use}} by using protocols to populate {{c1::forwarding tables of data plane elements}}.
  • {{c1::Management}} plane: These are services that are used to {{c1::monitor and configure}} the control functionality, e.g. {{c1::SNMP}}-based tools.

Software-defined network apprach has several advantages:

Shared abstractions: These {{c1::middlebox services}} (or network functionalities) can be {{c1::programmed}} easily now that the abstractions provided by the {{c1::control platform}} and {{c1::network programming languages}} can be shared.

Consistency of same network information: All network applications have the same {{c1::global network information view}}, leading to {{c1::consistent policy}} decisions while reusing control plane modules

Locality of functionality placement: Previously, the {{c1::location of middleboxes}} was a strategic decision and big constraint. However, in the SDN model, the {{c1::middlebox applications}} can take actions from {{c1::anywhere}} in the network.

Similar to traditional networks, an SDN infrastructure consists of {{c1::networking equipment}} ({{c1::routers}}, {{c1::switches}} and other {{c1::middlebox hardware}}). What is now different is that these physical networking equipment are merely {{c1::forwarding}} elements that do a simple {{c1::forwarding}} task, and any logic to operate them is directed from the centralized control system. Popular examples of such infrastructure equipment include {{c1::OpenFlow}} {{c1::(software) switches}} such as {{c1::SwitchLight}}, {{c1::Open vSwitch}}, {{c1::Pica8}}, etc.

{{c1::Southbound}} interfaces: These are interfaces that act as {{c1::connecting bridges}} between {{c1::control}} and {{c1::forwarding}} elements, and since they sit in between {{c1::control}} and {{c1::data}} plane, they play a crucial role in separating control and {{c1::data}} plane functionality. These APIs are {{c1::tightly}} coupled with the {{c1::forwarding}} elements of the underlying {{c1::physical or virtual}} infrastructure. The most popular implementation of Southbound APIs for SDNs is {{c1::OpenFlow}},

{{c1::Network virtualization}}: For a complete virtualization of the network, the {{c1::network infrastructure}} needs to provide support for arbitrary network topologies and addressing schemes, similar to the computing layer. Existing virtualization constructs such as {{c1::VLAN}}, {{c1::NAT}} and {{c1::MLPS}} are able to provide full network virtualization, however these technologies are connected by a {{c1::box-by-box}} basis configuration and there is no {{c1::unifying abstraction}} that can be leveraged to configure these in a global manner, thereby making current network provisioning tasks as long as months and years.

{{c1::Network operating systems:}} The promise of SDN is to ease {{c1::network management}} and solve {{c1::networking problems}} by using a logically centralized controller by way of a {{c1::network operating system (NOS).}}
{{c1::OpenFlow}} is used in the {{c1::control}} plane, and it is an example of a {{c1::northbound}} interface.

In an {{c1::OpenFlow}} device, when a packet arrives, the lookup process starts in the first table and ends either with a match in one of the tables of the pipeline or with a miss (when no rule is found for that packet). Some possible actions for the packet include:
  1. {{c1::Forward}} the packet to {{c1::outgoing}} port
  2. {{c1::Encapsulate}} the packet and {{c1::forward}} it to controller
  3. {{c1::Drop}} the packet
  4. {{c1::Send}} the packet to {{c1::normal processing pipeline}}
  5. {{c1::Send}} the packet to next {{c1::flow table}}
The {{c1::Southbound}} interfaces or APIs are the separating medium between the {{c1::control}} plane and {{c1::data}} plane functionality.

Currently , {{c1::OpenFlow}} is the most widely accepted {{c2::southbound}} standard for SDNs. It provides specification to implement OpenFlow-enabled {{c3::forwarding}} devices, and for the communication channel between {{c4::data}} and {{c5::control}} plane devices.

There are three information sources provided by OpenFlow protocol:
  1. {{c1::Event-based}} messages that are sent by {{c2::forwarding}} devices to controller when there is a link or port change
  2. {{c3::Flow}} statistics are generated by {{c4::forwarding}} devices and collected by {{c5::controller}}
  3. {{c6::Packet}} messages are sent by {{c7::forwarding}} devices to {{c1::controller}} when they {{c8::do not know}} what to do with a new incoming flow 
These three channels are key to provide flow-level info to the Network Operating System (NOS).

Sends a message to the controller

SDN Controllers can be categorized based on {{c1::centralized}} or {{c2::distributed}} architecture.

In Centralized controller architecture, we typically see a {{c1::single entity}} that manages {{c2::all forwarding}} devices in the network, which is a {{c3::single point of failure}} and may have {{c4::scaling issues}}. Also, a single controller may not be enough to handle {{c5::a large number of data}} plane elements.

{{c1::Distributed}} network operating system (controller) can be {{c1::scaled}} to meet the requirements of potentially any environment - {{c1::small or large}} networks. Distribution can occur in two ways:
  • {{c1::centralized cluster}} of nodes
  • {{c1::physically distributed}} set of elements.

Typically,  a cloud provider that runs across multiple data centers interconnected by a WAN may require a {{c1::hybrid}} approach to distribution - clusters of controllers inside each data center and {{c2::distributed}} controller nodes in different sites.

econfigurability: The way {{c1::parsing}} and {{c2::processing}} of packets takes place in the switches should be {{c3::modifiable}} by the controller.

Protocol independence: To enable the switches to be {{c1::independent}} of any particular protocol, the controller defines a {{c2::packet parser}} and a set of tables mapping {{c3::matches}} and their {{c4::actions}}. The packet parser extracts the {{c5::header fields}} which are then passed on to the {{c6::match+action tables}} to be processed.

arget independence: The packet processing programs should be programmed i{{c1::ndependent of}} the underlying {{c2::target devices}}. The P4 model allows generalization of {{c1::packet processing}} across various {{c2::forwarding devices}} such as routers, load balancers, etc., using multiple technologies such as fixed function switches, NPUs, etc.

The two main operations of the P4 forwarding model: 
  1. {{c1::Configure}}: These sets of operations are used to {{c2::program the parser}}. They specify the {{c3::header fields}} to be processed in each {{c4::match+action}} stage and also define the order of these stages. 
  2. {{c4::Populate}}: The entries in the {{c5::match+action}} tables specified during configuration may be altered using the {{c6::populate operations}}. It allows {{c7::addition}} and {{c8::deletion}} of the entries in the tables.
{{c1::configuration}} determines the p{{c2::acket processing}} and the {{c3::supported protocols}} in a switch whereas {{c4::population}} decides the {{c5::policies to be applied}} to the packets.

GP hijacking attacks can be classified into the following groups:
  1. Classification by {{c1::Affected Prefix}}
  2. Classification by {{c2::AS-Path announcement}}
  3. Classification by {{c3::Data-Plane traffic manipulation}}

What are the categories related to Classification by Affected Prefix:
  • {{c1::Exact prefix}} hijacking
  • {{c2::Sub-prefix}} hijacking
  • {{c3::Squatting}}

When two different ASes (one is genuine and the other one is counterfeit) announce a path for the same prefix. This disrupts routing in such a way that traffic is routed towards the hijacker wherever the AS-path route is shortest, thereby disrupting traffic.

This is an extension of exact prefix hijacking, except that in this case, the hijacking AS works with a sub-prefix of the genuine prefix of the real AS. This exploits the characteristic of BGP to favor more specific prefixes, and as a result route large/entire amount of traffic to the hijacking AS.
In this type of attack, the hijacking AS announces a prefix that has not yet been announced by the owner AS.

Three types of Classification by AS-Path announcement
  1. {{c1::Type-0}} hijacking
  2. {{c2::Type-N}} hijacking
  3. {{c3::Type-U}} hijacking
This is simply an AS announcing a prefix not owned by itself.
This is an attack where the counterfeit AS announces an illegitimate path for a prefix that it does not own to create a fake link (path) between different ASes.
In this attack the hijacking AS does not modify the AS-PATH but may change the prefix.

Broadly viewed, the attacks can be classified as caused by:
  1. {{c1::Human Error}}
  2. {{c2::Targeted}} Attack
  3. {{c3::High Impact}} Attack

This is an accidental routing misconfiguration due to manual errors. This can lead to large scale exact-prefix hijacking. e.g: China Telecom accidentally leaked a full BGP table that led to large-scale Type-0 hijacking

In this type of attack, the hijacking AS usually intercepts network traffic (MM attack) while operating in stealth mode to remain under the radar on the control plane (Type-N and Type-U attacks). e.g: Visa and Mastercard’s traffic were hijacked by Russian networks using this method in 2017

The attacker is obvious in their intent to cause widespread disruption of services. e.g: Pakistan Telecom in a Type-0 sub-prefix hijacking, essentially blackholing all of YouTube’s services worldwide for nearly 2 hours.
We can say that the {{c1::motivation}} behind every hijacking attempt is {{c1::different}}

The ARTEMIS system uses two automated techniques in mitigating BGP hijacking attacks:
  1. {{c1::Prefix}} deaggregation
  2. {{c2::Mitigation with Multiple Origin AS (MOAS)}}
In a BGP attack scenario, the affected network can either contact other networks or it can simply deaggregate the prefixes that were targeted by announcing more specific prefixes of a certain prefix.
Having third party organizations and service providers do BGP announcements for a given network.

In MOAS when a BGP hijacking event occurs, the following steps occur:
  1. The third party receives a {{c1::notification}} and immediately {{c1::announces}} from their locations the {{c1::hijacked prefix(es).}} 
  2. In this way, {{c2::network traffic}} from across the world is {{c2::attracted}} to the third party organization, which then {{c2::scrubbs it and tunnels}} it to the legitimate AS.

As the name suggests, in packet dropping, all network traffic going to a set of specific IP addresses is discarded. The censor identifies undesirable traffic and chooses to not properly forward any packets it sees associated with the traversing undesirable traffic instead of following a normal routing protocol.

Blocks the entire domain. It is not possible to allow email contact while blocking the website.

Proxy-based content inspection: This censorship technique is more sophisticated, in that it allows for all network traffic to pass through a proxy where the traffic is examined for content, and the proxy rejects requests that serve objectionable content.

1. Precise censorship: A very precise level of censorship can be achieved, down to the level of single web pages or even objects within the web page.
  2. Flexible: Works well with hybrid security systems. E.g., with a combination of other censorship techniques like packet dropping and DNS poisoning.
Not scalable: They are expensive to implement on a large scale network as the processing overhead is large (through a proxy)

An alternative approach is to use parts of an IDS to inspect network traffic. An IDS is easier and more cost effective to implement than a proxy based system as it is more responsive than reactive in nature, in that it informs the firewall rules for future censorship.

Augur is a method and accompanying system that utilizes {{c1::TCP/IP side channels}} to measure reachability (if there is any filtering) between two Internet locations without directly controlling a {{c1::measurement vantage point}} at either location.
Suppose we are using Augur to detect filtering between two host, and that we have a scenario where no blocking occurs. The measurement machine sends a SYN-ACK to the reflector. What should happen?
The return IP ID from the reflector to the measurement machine should increase by 2.
Assume a scenario we are using Augur to detect inbound blocking. The Measurement Machine sends a SYN-ACK to the reflector, what should happen?
The return IPID from the reflector to the Measurement Machine will increase by 1.
Assume a scenario we are using Augur to detect outbound blocking. The Measurement Machine has not recieved responses to two if its SYN-ACKs to the reflector, what should happen?
The return IPID from the reflector to the Measurement Machine will increase by 2 for each SYN-ACK sent without a returned RST. Thus showing retransmission.
